docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: DIVISION 5 WINDING UP PROCEEDINGS (INCLUDING OPPRESSION PROCEEDINGS WHERE WINDING UP IS SOUGHT) [rr 5.1–5.11]

heading.title: DIVISION 5 WINDING UP PROCEEDINGS (INCLUDING OPPRESSION PROCEEDINGS WHERE WINDING UP IS SOUGHT) [rr 5.1–5.11]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: DIVISION 5 WINDING UP PROCEEDINGS (INCLUDING OPPRESSION PROCEEDINGS WHERE WINDING UP IS SOUGHT) [rr 5.1–5.11]

leg:heading.title: WINDING UP PROCEEDINGS (INCLUDING OPPRESSION PROCEEDINGS WHERE WINDING UP IS SOUGHT) [rr 5.1–5.11]

p.text: This Division applies to the following applications for the winding up of a company:
an application under Part 5.4 or Part 5.4A of the Corporations Act.
[r 5.1 am Gaz 168 of 22 December 2000 p 13608 ; Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,345] r 5.2 Affidavit accompanying statutory demand (Corporations Act s 459E(3)) — Form 7

leg:heading.title: Affidavit accompanying statutory demand (Corporations Act s 459E(3) ) — Form 7

p.text: For the purposes of subsection 459E(3) of the Corporations Act, the affidavit accompanying a statutory demand relating to a debt, or debts, owed by a company must:
be in accordance with Form 7 and state the matters mentioned in that Form; and
be made by the creditor or by a person with the authority of the creditor or creditors; and
not state a proceeding number, or refer to a Court proceeding, in any heading or title to the affidavit.
[r 5.2 am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
Legislation cited in [15,345.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court (Corporations) Rules 1999 r 1.7, Form 7.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 459Q(c), s 459J(1)(b).

The affidavit accompanying a statutory demand must be in accordance with Form 7 (see Forms Tab in vol 3) and state the matters mentioned in that form. The word “must” is to be read bearing in mind Supreme Court (Corporations) Rules 1999 r 1.7 , which provides that substantial compliance is sufficient: see also Dolvelle Pty Ltd v Australian Macfarms Pty Ltd (1998) 43 NSWLR 717 at 727; 155 ALR 151; BC9802003 per Santow J. Form 7 requires the following in paras 4 and 5:
4. The debt … mentioned in paragraph 1 of this affidavit is due and payable by the debtor company.
5. I believe that there is no genuine dispute about the existence or amount of the debt …

There is no real distinction, or if there is, it is a merely technical one, between believing that the debt is due and payable and saying that a debt is due and and payable and saying that a debt is due and payable: Grace Consulting Pty Ltd v Bourke Constructions Pty Ltd (2005) 54 ACSR 677; [2005] NSWSC 836; BC200506194 at [18]–[27] per Young J. The affidavit should verify the indebtedness at the date the demand is made. An affidavit sworn at an earlier date does not comply with Corporations Act 2001 s 459Q(c) . The legislative scheme envisages not only that a company which claims to be a creditor will state in the demand itself that the debt is due and payable but also that some human being acting with the authority of that company and capable of swearing an affidavit will independently form and state an opinion that the debt is due and payable: Saferack Pty Ltd v Marketing Heads Australia Pty Ltd [2007] NSWSC 1143; BC200708777 at [39]–[41] . A statement that the company is “indebted” to the creditor (rather than the debt is “due and payable”) is insufficient as it connotes no more than that the debt exists: Saferack Pty Ltd v Marketing Heads Australia Pty Ltd, above at [40]–[41] (affidavit held not to comply). Failure to state in the affidavit that the deponent believes that there is no genuine dispute about the existence or amount of the debt is fatal: Saferack Pty Ltd v Marketing Heads Australia Pty Ltd, aboveat [42]–[43] (affidavit held not to comply).

Despite formal compliance with the rules, the source of the debt information in the supporting affidavit may be defective or unreliable. Such an appearance may provide a sufficient reason, under Corporations Act 2001 s 459J(1)(b) , to justify the demand being set aside: Walltech Building Systems Ltd v Gerlich [2008] NSWSC 1048; BC200808761 at [15] per Hammerschlag J; Standard Commodities Pty Ltd v Société Socinter Départment Centragel (2005) 54 ACSR 489; [2005] NSWSC294; BC200501856 at [15] per Barrett J (the creditor could not be regarded as the source of the information relied on to assert the debt).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,350] r 5.3 Application for leave to apply for winding up in insolvency (Corporations Act s 459P(2))

leg:heading.title: Application for leave to apply for winding up in insolvency (Corporations Act s 459P(2) )

p.text: An application for leave to apply to the Court for an order that a company be wound up in insolvency may be made at the same time as the application for an order that the company be wound up in insolvency is made.
[r 5.3 am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
Legislation cited in [15,350.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 459P(2)(a).

A contingent or prospective creditor requires the leave of the Court to bring an application to wind up a company: s 459P(2)(a) . However, in accordance with well established principles, in the absence of a clear statutory indication to the contrary, leave may in fact be granted retrospectively: Australian Beverage Distributors Pty Ltd v Evans & Tate Premium Wines Pty Ltd (2007) 61 ACSR 441; 25 ACLC 230; [2007] NSWCA 57; BC200701811 at [11]–[12] per Beazley JA (Hodgson and Santow JJA agreeing).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,355] r 5.4 Affidavit in support of application for winding up (Corporations Act s 459P, s 462, s 464)

leg:heading.title: Affidavit in support of application for winding up (Corporations Act s 459P , s 462 , s 464 )

p.text: The affidavit in support of an originating process seeking an order that a company be wound up must be made by the plaintiff or by a person with the authority of the plaintiff or plaintiffs.
[subr (1) am Gaz 48 of 5 April 2007 p 2118, effective 5 April 2007]
If the application is made in reliance on a failure by the company to comply with a statutory demand, the affidavit must:
verify service of the demand on the company; and
verify the failure of the company to comply with the demand; and
state whether and, if so, to what extent the debt, or each of the debts, to which the demand relates is still due and payable by the company at the date when the affidavit is made.
An example of the affidavit in support of an application for winding up in insolvency for failure to comply with a statutory demand is shown in Schedule 2 (Notes to these Rules).
If the application is made in reliance on the ground mentioned in paragraph 461(1)(a) of the Corporations Act, the affidavit must:
state whether the company is able to pay all its debts as and when they become due and payable; and
refer to the company's most recent balance sheet and profit and loss statement as an annexure or exhibit to the affidavit, or explain their absence.
[subr (3) am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
The affidavit must be made within 7 days before the originating process is filed.
[r 5.4 am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
Legislation cited in [15,355.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 459F(2)(a), s 459G.

Where an application to set aside a statutory demand (a “ s 459G application”) is properly initiated within 21 days of service of the statutory demand, the period for compliance with the statutory demand is determined under Corporations Act 2001 s 459F(2)(a) and depends on the final disposition of the s 459G application. No application to wind up the company based solely on alleged failure to comply with the statutory demand can properly be filed until after the s 459G application has been determined: Long Nominees Pty Ltd v Roandale Holdings Pty Ltd [2009] NSWSC 932; BC200908190 at [7]–[15] per Barrett J (application and affidavit premature — proceedings dismissed with indemnity costs).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,360] r 5.5 Consent of liquidator (Corporations Act s 532(9)) — Form 8

leg:heading.title: Consent of liquidator (Corporations Act s 532(9) ) — Form 8

p.text: [subr (1A) rep Amendment 340: Gaz 81 of 30 June 2000 p 5789]
In this rule:
does not include a provisional liquidator.
For the purposes of subsection 532(9) of the Corporations Act, the consent of an official liquidator to act as liquidator of a company must be in accordance with Form 8 .
[subr (2) am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
In an application for an order that a company be wound up, the plaintiff must:
before the hearing of the application, file the consent mentioned in subrule (2) of an official liquidator who would be entitled to be appointed as liquidator of the company; and
serve a copy of the consent on the company at least 1 day before the hearing.
[r 5.5 am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,365] r 5.6 Notice of application for winding up — Form 9

leg:heading.title: Notice of application for winding up — Form 9

p.text: Unless the Court otherwise orders, the plaintiff must publish a notice of the application for an order that a company be wound up.
The notice must be:
in accordance with Form 9 ; and
published in accordance with rule 2.11 :
at least 3 days after the originating process is served on the company, and
at least 7 days before the date fixed for hearing of the application.
[subr (2) am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004 ; Gaz 91 of 28 May 2004 p 3287, effective 28 May 2004]

The rule has been consistently interpreted so as to prohibit publication of the winding up proceedings other than by a complying notice. The rule thus prohibits publication by press release: Australian Beverage Distributors Pty Ltd v Evans & Tate Premium Wines Pty Ltd (2007) 61 ACSR 441; 25 ACLC 230; [2007] NSWCA 57; BC200701811 at [84]–[85] ; or circulation of creditors: see Re A Company 001127 of 1992 (1992) 10 ACLC 3,035: Paterson v Hampton Interiors (1989) 7 ACLC 904 at 905-906; BC8902068 (summons advertised before served – summons dismissed as an abuse of process). It seems that the fact a listed company may itself be under an obligation to publicise the application to the ASX, or that ASIC may publish the Form 509 notice on its database does not affect the operation of the rule: Australian Beverage Distributors Pty Ltd v Evans & Tate Premium Wines Pty Ltd (2007) 61ACSR 441; 25 ACLC 230; [2007] NSWCA 57; BC200701811 at [97], [108] per Beazley JA (Hodgson and Santow JJA agreeing).
Legislation cited in [15,365.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

An application to wind up a corporation must be published: s 465A Corporations Act. The applicant must lodge with ASIC notice in the prescribed form (Form 509H Corporations Act Forms) not later than 10.30 am on the next business day after the filing of the application, and within 14 days after the application is made, serve a copy of the notice on the company: ss 465A and 470(1)(a) Corporations Act. If the application is withdrawn or dismissed, the applicant must lodge with ASIC, within 2 business days after the withdrawal or dismissal of the application, notice of the withdrawal or dismissal of the application. There is no requirement to serve a copy of the notice to ASIC on the company: CMA Corp Ltd v SNL Group Pty Ltd [2009] NSWSC 1452; BC200911648 at [5]–[7] per Austin J.

When the notice to be lodged with ASIC is lodged outside the time specified in s 470(1)(a) the court can in an appropriate case extend the time for lodgement of that notice by order made under s 1322(4)(d) of the Corporations Act: MFS Alternative Assets (in liq) v Angstrom Assets Pty Ltd [2012] NSWSC 447; BC201203280 at [5] (time extended where lodgement was outside the time permitted by reason of delays arising from difficulty in serving the application upon the director of the defendant company).
Legislation cited in [15,365.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 467A.

Mere irregularity in publication does not justify dismissal of a winding up application: see s 467A Corporations Act; Kozlowski v JSBG Developments Pty Ltd [2010] NSWSC 1022; BC201006605 per White J (winding up order made notwithstanding the application had not been advertised — no evidence of creditors other than the plaintiff, no prejudice shown). For example, it is an inappropriate ground for dismissal if the irregular publication causes no prejudice: Re D R Electrical and Engineering Pty Ltd (1989) 7 ACLC 1,058 and Re Jazzamint Pty Ltd (1990) 8 ACLC 763; BC9000888 (held that the company was not prejudiced by the premature advertising); Melcann Ltd v Marmlon Holdings Pty Ltd (1991) 4 ACSR 736; BC9102038 (unintentional breach — winding up not opposed). In the absence of established or apprehended prejudice, the court may dispense with publication: Dikwa Holdings Pty Ltd v Oakbury Pty Ltd (1992) 36 FCR 274; (1992) 8 ACSR 53 . Irregular publication may involve more than mere inadvertence or ignorance and may actually involve abuse of process: Australian Beverage Distributors Pty Ltd v Evans & Tate Premium Wines Pty Ltd (2007) 61 ACSR 441; 25 ACLC 230; [2007] NSWCA 57; BC200701811 at [84]–[85] . The orders that a court may make when there is an abuse of process include dismissal, stay or injunction: see Australian Beverage Distributors Pty Ltd v Evans & Tate Premium Wines Pty Ltd, above, at [126]. David Grant & Co Pty Ltd (Receiver Appointed) v Westpac Banking Corporation (1995) 184 CLR 265; 131 ALR 353; 18 ACSR 225; [1995] HCA 43 ; Fortuna Holdings Pty Ltd v Deputy Commissioner of Taxation [1978] VR 83; (1976) 2 ACLR 349 ; Re Jeff Reid Pty Ltd and the Companies Act (1980) 5 ACLR 28 . The court dispensed with the requirement for publication where the application related to the appointment of existing receivers and managers as liquidators: Commonwealth v ABC2 Group Pty Ltd (Ct-apptd recs & mgrs apptd) [2009] NSWSC 1442; BC200911525 at [22] per Austin J.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,370] r 5.7 Applicant to make copies of documents available

leg:heading.title: Applicant to make copies of documents available

p.text: A copy of any document filed in a proceeding to which this Division applies must be available at the plaintiff's address for service for inspection by a creditor, contributory or officer of the company, or an officer of a creditor or contributory of the company.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,375] r 5.8 Discontinuance of application for winding up

leg:heading.title: Discontinuance of application for winding up

p.text: An application for an order that a company be wound up may not be discontinued except with the leave of the Court.
After filing an originating process seeking an order that a company be wound up, the plaintiff must, if required:
appear before the Registrar on a date to be appointed by the Registrar; and
satisfy the Registrar that the plaintiff has complied with the Corporations Act and these Rules in relation to applications for a winding up order.
[r 5.9 am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,385] r 5.10 Order substituting plaintiff in application for winding up (Corporations Act s 465B) — Form 10

leg:heading.title: Order substituting plaintiff in application for winding up (Corporations Act s 465B ) — Form 10

p.text: If the Court makes an order under section 465B of the Corporations Act, the Court may also order that the substituted plaintiff or plaintiffs publish a notice stating that the substituted plaintiff or plaintiffs intend to apply for an order that the company be wound up.
[subr (1) am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
The notice must be:
in accordance with Form 10 ; and
published:
in accordance with rule 2.11 at least 7 days before the date fixed for the hearing of the application, or
as otherwise directed by the Court.
[subr (2) am Gaz 91 of 28 May 2004 p 3287, effective 28 May 2004]
[r 5.10 am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,390] r 5.11 Notice of winding up order and appointment of liquidator — Form 11

leg:heading.title: Notice of winding up order and appointment of liquidator — Form 11

p.text: This rule applies if the Court orders that a company be wound up and an official liquidator be appointed as liquidator of the company.
Not later than the day after the order is made, the plaintiff must inform the liquidator of the appointment.
As soon as practicable after being informed of the appointment, the liquidator must publish a notice of the winding up order and the liquidator's appointment.
The notice must be:
in accordance with Form 11 ; and
published in accordance with rule 2.11 .
In this rule:
does not include a provisional liquidator.
